Sentences: Good afternoon.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: At the Federal Reserve, we are strongly committed to achieving the monetary policy goals that Congress has given us:  maximum employment and price stability.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Since the beginning of the pandemic, we have taken forceful actions to provide relief and stability, to ensure that the recovery will be as strong as possible, and to limit lasting damage to the economy.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Today my colleagues on the FOMC and I kept interest rates near zero and maintained our sizable asset purchases.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: These measures, along with our strong guidance on interest rates and our balance sheet, will ensure that monetary policy will continue to deliver powerful support to the economy until the recovery is complete.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The path of the economy continues to depend significantly on the course of the virus.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: A resurgence in recent months in COVID-19 cases, hospitalizations, and deaths is causing great hardship for millions of Americans and is weighing on economic activity and job creation.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Following a sharp rebound in economic activity last summer, the pace of the recovery has moderated in recent months, with the weakness concentrated in the sectors of the economy most adversely affected by the resurgence of the virus and by greater social distancing.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Household spending on services remains low, especially in sectors that typically require people to gather closely, including travel and hospitality.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And household spending on goods has moderated following earlier large gains.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: In contrast, the housing sector has more than fully recovered from the downturn, supported in part by low mortgage interest rates.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Business investment and manufacturing production have also picked up.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The overall recovery in economic activity since last spring is due in part to federal stimulus payments and expanded unemployment benefits, which have provided essential support to many families and individuals.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The recently enacted Coronavirus support.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Overall economic activity remains below its level before the pandemic, and the path ahead remains highly uncertain.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: As with overall economic activity, the pace of improvement in the labor market has slowed in recent months.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Employment fell by 140,000 in December, as continued gains in many industries were outweighed by significant losses in industries where the resurgence of the virus has weighed further on activity.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: In particular, the leisure and hospitality sector lost nearly half a million jobs, largely from restaurants and bars.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The unemployment rate remained elevated at 6.7 percent in December, and participation in the labor market is notably below pre-pandemic levels.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Although there has been much progress in the labor market since the spring, millions of Americans remain out of work.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The economic downturn has not fallen equally on all Americans, and those least able to shoulder the burden have been the hardest hit.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: In particular, the high level of joblessness has been especially severe for lower-wage workers in the service sector and for African Americans and Hispanics.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The economic dislocation has upended many lives and created great uncertainty about the future.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The pandemic has also left a significant imprint on inflation.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Following large declines in the spring, consumer prices picked up over the summer but have leveled out more recently.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: For those sectors that have been most adversely affected by the pandemic, prices remain particularly soft.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Overall, on a 12-month basis, inflation remains below our 2 percent longer-run objective.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: While we should not underestimate the challenges we currently face, several developments point to an improved outlook for later this year.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Sufficiently widespread vaccinations would enable us to put the pandemic behind us and return to more normal economic activities.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: In the meantime, continued observance of social-distancing measures and wearing households and businesses weather the downturn as well as limit lasting damage to the economy that could otherwise impede the recovery.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: In addition, as we have seen since last summer, the economy has proved more resilient than expected, in part reflecting the adaptability of households and businesses.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Finally, monetary policy is playing a key role in supporting the recovery and will continue to do so.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The Fed’s response to this crisis has been guided by our mandate to promote maximum employment and stable prices for the American people, along with our responsibilities to promote the stability of the financial system.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Today we unanimously reaffirmed our Statement on Longer-Run Goals and Monetary Policy Strategy, as we typically do each January.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: As we say in that statement, we view maximum employment as a “broad-based and inclusive goal.”  Our ability to achieve maximum employment in the years ahead depends importantly on having longer-term inflation expectations well anchored at 2 percent.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: As the Committee reiterated in today’s policy statement, with inflation running persistently below 2 percent, we will aim to achieve inflation moderately above 2 percent for some time so that inflation averages 2 percent over time and longer-term inflation expectations remain well anchored at 2 percent.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We expect to maintain an accommodative stance of monetary policy until these employment and inflation outcomes are achieved.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: With regard to interest rates, we continue to expect it will be appropriate to maintain the current 0 to ¼ percent target range for the federal funds rate until labor market conditions have reached levels consistent with the Committee’s assessment of maximum employment and inflation has risen to 2 percent and is on track to moderately exceed 2 percent for some time.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: In addition, we will continue to increase our holdings of Treasury securities by at least $80 billion per month and of agency mortgage-backed toward our maximum-employment and price-stability goals.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The increase in our balance sheet since last March has materially eased financial conditions and is providing substantial support to the economy.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The economy is a long way from our employment and inflation goals, and it is likely to take some time for substantial further progress to be achieved.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Our forward guidance for the federal funds rate, along with our balance sheet guidance, will ensure that the stance of monetary policy remains highly accommodative as the recovery progresses.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Our guidance is outcome based and ties the path of the federal funds rate and the balance sheet to progress toward reaching our employment and inflation goals.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Thus, if progress toward our goals were to slow, the guidance would convey our intention to increase policy accommodation through a lower expected path of the federal funds rate and a higher expected path of the balance sheet.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Overall, our interest rate and balance sheet tools are providing powerful support to the economy and will continue to do so.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We’ve also taken actions to more directly support the flow of credit in the economy, deploying our emergency lending powers to an unprecedented extent, enabled in large part by financial backing and support from Congress and the Treasury.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Although the CARES Act facilities are no—are no longer open to new activity, our other facilities remain in place.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: To conclude, we understand that our actions affect communities, families, and businesses across the country.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Everything we do is in service to our public mission.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We are committed to using our full range of tools to support the economy and to help assure that the recovery from this difficult period will be as robust as possible.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: I look forward to your questions.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Jeanna Smialek.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Thank you for taking our questions.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: It’s just not really something that I would typically comment on.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: In terms of macroprudential policy tools, so, as you know, no doubt, we rely on sort of always-on, through-the-cycle macroprudential policy tools, particularly the stress tests and also the elevated levels of liquidity and capital and, and, and also resolution planning that we—that we impose on the largest financial institutions.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We don’t use time-varying tests and tools as some other countries do.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And we think it’s a good approach because—for us to use ones that are always-on—because we don’t really think we’d be successful in every case in picking the exact right time to intervene in markets.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So that’s for banks.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: You really asked about nonbanks, the nonbank sector.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And so we monitor financial conditions very broadly.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And while we don’t have jurisdiction over, over many areas in the nonbank sector, other agencies do.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And so we do coordinate through the Financial Stability Oversight Council and with other agencies who have responsibility for, for nonbank supervision.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: and the dislocations that we saw from the outsized economic and financial shock of the pandemic really appeared in the nonbank sector.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So that’s—right now we are engaged in, in carefully examining, understanding, and thinking about what, what in the nonbank sector will need to be addressed in the next year or so.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Thank you so much, Michelle and Chair Powell.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: I had a question on fiscal policy.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: So I guess I’d start by saying that the, the fiscal response that we’ve seen to this downturn has been strong, and I think we can say now that it’s been sustained after the passage of the—of the, the most recent act in, in late December.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And that’s really a key reason why the recovery has been as strong as it’s been.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Fiscal policy has been absolutely essential.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: When we look back on, on the history of this period, we’ll see a strong and sustained fiscal policy response.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: I would—I would add that we’re, as I mentioned, a long way from a full recovery.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: That’s as many people as lost their jobs at the peak of the Global Financial Crisis and the Great Recession.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Many small businesses are under pressure, and there are other needs to be addressed.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And the path ahead is still pretty uncertain.

Sentences: So there’s a discussion, as you know, right now around, around those precise questions, and, and that’s appropriate, but not for us to play a role in talking about specific policies.

Sentences: Steve Liesman.

Sentences: I wonder if I could follow up on Jeanna’s question here.

Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Sentences: But from Bitcoin to corporate bonds to the stock market in general to some of these more specific meteoric rises in stocks like GameStop, how do you address the concern that super easy monetary policy—asset purchases and zero interest rates—are potentially fueling a bubble that could cause economic fallout should it burst?

Sentences: Let me—let me provide a little context.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The shock that the—from the pandemic was unprecedented both in its nature and in its size and in the amount of unemployment that it created and in the shock to economic activity.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: There’s nothing close to it in our modern economic history.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So our response was really to that.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And we—we’ve done what we could, first, to restore market function and to provide a bit of relief, then to support the recovery.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And, hopefully, we’ll be able to do the third thing, which is to avoid longer-run damage to the—to the economy.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Our role assigned by Congress is maximum employment and stable prices and also look after financial stability.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So, in a world where, almost a year later, we’re, we’re still 9 million jobs, at least—that’s one way of counting it; it can actually be counted much higher than that—short of maximum employment and people are out of the labor force who were in the labor labor force—it’s very much appropriate that monetary policy be highly accommodative to support maximum employment and price stability, which is getting inflation back to 2 percent and averaging 2 percent over time.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So, on, on matters of financial stability, we have a framework.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We don’t look at one thing or two things.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We look at—and we made that framework public after the financial crisis so that it could be criticized and understood and we could be held accountable.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And, you know, the things that we look at are—we do look at asset prices.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We also look at leverage in the banking system.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We look at leverage in the non—the nonbanking system, which is to say, corporates and households.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And we look at also funding risk.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And if you look at it across that range of, of, of readings, they’re each different, but we monitor them carefully.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And I would say that financial stability vulnerabilities overall are moderate.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Our overall goal is to assure that the financial system itself is resilient to, to shocks of all kinds, that it’s strong and resilient.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And that includes not just the banks, but money market funds and, and all different kinds of nonbank financial structures as well.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So when we get to the nonfinancial sector, we don’t—we don’t have jurisdiction over that.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But—so I would just say that our—that there are many things that go in, as you know, to, to setting asset prices.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And it’s also financial—sorry, fiscal policy.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So I, I know that monetary policy does play a role there, but that’s how we look at it.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And I think, you know, I think that the connection between low interest rates and, and asset different factors are driving asset prices at any given time.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Can I follow up, Michelle, if you don’t mind?
Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Sentences: Mr. Chairman, do you rule out or see as one of your tools in the toolkit the idea of adjusting monetary policy to address asset values?
Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Sentences: So, you know, that’s—as you know, that’s one of the very difficult questions in all of monetary policy.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And we don’t rule it out as a theoretical matter, but we, we clearly look to macroprudential tools, regulatory tools, supervisory tools, other kinds of tools rather than monetary policy in, in addressing financial stability issues.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: It’s not—you know, the, the monetary policy we know strengthens economic activity and job creation through fairly well-understood channels.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And a strong economy is actually a great supporter of financial stability.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: That will mean strong, you know, well-capitalized institutions, and, and households will be—will be working.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And, and so we know that.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We don’t actually understand the tradeoff between—the sense of it is, would you—if you raise interest rates and thereby tighten financial conditions and reduce economic activity now in order to address asset bubbles and things like that, what—will that even help?
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Will it—will it actually cause more damage, or will it help?
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So I think that’s unresolved.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And I, I think it’s, it’s something we, we look at as not, not theoretically ruled out but not something we, we—we’ve ever done and not something we would plan to do.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We would rely on macroprudential and other tools to deal with financial stability issues.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Thank you.

Sentences: So, on inflation, a couple of things—there are a couple of things that are worth mentioning.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: One is just that we know that we measure inflation on a trailing 12-month basis.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And as we—as we lap the very low inflation readings of March and April of last year, we’ll see measured 12-month inflation move up a few tenths.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: This is just—they’re called base effects, and, and that’s a—that’s a transient thing that we think will pass.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: There’s also the possibility—indeed, it’s in some forecasts—that as the economy fully reopens, there’ll be a burst of spending, and—because people will be enthusiastic that the pandemic is over, potentially, and that that could also create some upward pressure on inflation.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Now, again, we would see that as something likely to be transient and not to be very large.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: In both cases, we don’t see those as either lasting or particularly large.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So the way we would react is, we’re going to be patient.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Expect us to wait and see and not react if we see small and what we would review—we would view as very likely to be transient effects on inflation.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: I think if you—you know, it helps to look back at, at the inflation dynamics that the United States has had now for some decades and notice that there has been, you know, significant disinflationary pressure for some time, for a couple of decades.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Inflation has averaged less than 2 percent for a quarter of a century.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And the inflation dynamics, with the flat Phillips curve and low persistence of inflation, is very much intact.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Those things, they change over time.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We understand that inflation dynamics evolve constantly over time, but they don’t know, troubling inflation.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Of course, if we did get sustained inflation at a level that was uncomfortable, we have tools for that.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: It’s far harder to deal with, with too low inflation.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We know what to do with higher inflation, which is, you know, should the need arise, we, we would have those tools.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And we don’t expect to see that at all.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: In terms of how much, you know, what we’ve said is we’d like to see—because inflation has been running persistently below 2 percent, we’d like to see it run moderately above 2 percent for some time.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We have not adopted a formula.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We’re not going to adopt a formula.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We’re going to—we, we use policy rules and formulas in everything we do, consult them constantly, but we don’t set policy by them.

Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But the question is getting them back to work.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And, you know, it’s, it’s harder if you’re—it takes longer, empirically, to find that next job if you’re looking at a brand-new industry.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: It’s not easy to change careers completely midcareer.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So that just, again, stresses the job and getting back to a place where it’s safe to have these—you know, to, to, to stay in hotels, to fly on airplanes, to go to sporting events and movie theaters, and all of those things.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So those people are still at risk.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And we’re, we’re very, very focused on that group of people with our policy and, and, and, you know, the way we look at the economy.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So many people have had that bridge across the pandemic.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: You know, we talked about that at the beginning.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: For many people, it’s clear that they’ve made it across, and their job is okay, and their house is okay.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And, you know, it’s been terribly inconvenient and painful, and schools are closed and things like that.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But there, there’s a bunch of people yet who haven’t found that bridge yet.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And we’re, we’re very focused on that.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Of course, the other thing is, we’re going to a different economy.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And we’re going to be learning more about that as we go.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But, clearly, we’re, we’re learning that things can be done from remote locations.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We’re learning that technology can replace people even more than we thought.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And some of that is happening.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So I think as we, you know, as we get into this, you know, the phase after—even after the economy fully reopens, I think we’re still going to need to keep people in mind whose lives have been disrupted, because they’ve lost that—the work that they did.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And I think it would be wise as a country, for the longer-run productive capacity of the country, if we were to look out for those people and help them find their way back into the labor force even if it means continuing support for an additional period of time.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Great.
Speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER.

Sentences: If I could ask this quick follow—yesterday Susan Rice, domestic policy advisor at the White House, talked about a Citigroup study that said closing racial economic gaps could add up to $5 trillion to the U.S. economy over the next five economy?
Speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER.

Sentences: And, if so, what can the Fed do proactively to narrow those racial gaps in income and wealth, including potentially through regulatory policy?
Speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER.

Sentences: I strongly agree with that, as a matter of fact.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: I think if you look at either—look at employment gaps or unemployment gaps or wage gaps, wealth gaps, homeowning gaps, all of those persistent gaps that exist even controlling for many other factors, you will see that they’re, they’re persistent, they’re—and they’re very difficult to explain.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And so it’s—the reason we talk about inequality and, and racial inequality in particular, is that it goes to our job, which is to achieve maximum employment, which, which links up with, with—we want—we want the potential output of the United States to be as high as it can possibly be.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We want—we want an economy where everybody can take part and everybody, everybody can put their labor in, and they can share in the prosperity of our great economy.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: That’s what we want.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And that’s how the U.S. economy can be bigger, stronger, growing faster, is if we can achieve a more—a broader prosperity.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So, now, in terms of our tools, you know, of course, that project that I just mentioned is one for the broader society, for the private sector, for fiscal policy, but we have a role to play.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And, and that is, how we think about the labor market.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Principally, when we say that the maximum employment is a, a broad and inclusive goal, what we’re—what we’re saying there is, we’re not just going to look at the headline—and we never did, really, but—we’re not going to just look at the headline numbers.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We’re going to look at different demographic groups, including women, minorities, and others.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And we’re not going to say that we’ve reached maximum employment, which is our statutory goal, until we’ve reached maximum employment.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: the labor market.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So those are the things that we can do.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We also do a tremendous amount of research on these issues.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: You know, we do—we, we have such a focus on these issues now that we actually—we, we have a new, a webpage, relatively new, where you can access all of it.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But it’s a lot of activities in our Division of Consumer and Community Affairs.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: It’s lots of research, and, and it’s also, you know, our enforcement of the fair lending laws and things like that.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So I think everybody’s got a role to play here.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: It’s a—it’s a national goal and a national job, and we’re just going to do our part of the job.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And it’s something we’re strongly committed to.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: For the last question, we’ll go to Scott Horsley at NPR.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Thanks, Mr. Chairman.
Speaker: SCOTT HORSLEY.

Sentences: You said in your opening remarks that the, the economy in many ways had proven more resilient than, than people expected, and that that reflected the adaptability of both households and businesses.
Speaker: SCOTT HORSLEY.

Sentences: Are, are there adaptations that caught you by surprise, maybe related to remote work or new ways to do on-site work, in-person, face-to-face work that, that the economy’s proven tougher than, than you expected at the outset of this pandemic?
Speaker: SCOTT HORSLEY.

Sentences: Well, yes.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So I think, if you go back to the—to the beginning, there was a real concern.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: I mean, just, just take the financial markets, for example.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Suddenly, all of those big buildings all over the, the—New York City and all around the world where people work in the financial markets with terminals and everything, everybody had to go home, and they had to take their terminals with them.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And I think there was a real concern that there would be a tremendous loss of functionality just at the time when the financial markets were under in the financial sector are still working with their terminals at home, including people on trading floors or on virtual trading floors.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Now, some of that’s reversing now.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But we have definitely learned that we can do more work from home in many, many different lines of work.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Of course, that’s not possible if your job involves being at a place, doing personal services.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: For many people, it’s not possible.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And that’s very much something that skews to higher-income, higher-educated people being able to work from home and others not so much.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So I think we’ve learned that.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The other thing, though, even conditional on that, when we saw the wave in the South and the West, the wave of cases this summer, I think, intuitively, having seen what happened in March and April, we expected there to be a significant hit to economic activity.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And people kind of just got on with their lives and went and, and dealt with it.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And, and it didn’t actually—it had a much smaller effect on economic activity than we expected.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Then comes the fall wave, which is just so much larger—a very, very large wave as, as was very much forecast.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: People going indoors, the cold weather, all of that.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And even there, if you look at—I would say, look at the December jobs report.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So, big job losses in, you know, in that part of the service sector.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So I mentioned 400,000 jobs in bars and restaurants.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: There’s another 100,000 in similar kinds of activities.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But if you go—if you look elsewhere, it’s not having an effect.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: You know, even purchasing manager index and sentiment indexes on, on areas of the economy that are not directly—really directly—exposed to the pandemic in their economic activity, they’re doing okay.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: They are.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Housing is a great example.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: You know, the way—the way—the way the housing industry worked, that when you buy a house, there was a lot of in-person contact.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: They managed able to completely avoid that.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And the housing market has been really strong, notwithstanding that it’s, it’s now quite virtual rather than in person.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So there’s been a lot of adapting, and—but you can’t adapt, you know, hotels, sporting venues, movie theaters, restaurants, bars.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: You just—you know, those are just going to—and that’s—again, that’s millions and millions of people.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And so you’re just going to have to defeat the pandemic, which, as I mentioned, you know, we, we have a plan to do that, but we haven’t done it yet.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And we need to—we need to finish the job.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And we—it’s, it’s within our power to do that as a country this year.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And I would just urge that—and I know people are working hard on that.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But that, that is really the main thing about the economy, is, is getting the pandemic under control, getting everyone vaccinated, getting people wearing masks, and all that.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: That’s the single most important economic growth policy that we can have.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.
